Currently, I am seeking a 6-month internship in the field of Data Science/Artificial Intelligence.

Google Summer of Code

Quantum Chemestry Developer - May 2024 - Sepemter 2024

Development of Open-Source Quantum Chemistry Software (ModelHamiltonian) Contributing to ModelHamiltonian, an open-source tool for generating 0, 1, and 2-electron integrals, supporting research in quantum chemistry, condensed matter physics, and materials science.

Key Contributions:

  • Designing user-friendly APIs for Pariser-Parr-Pople approximations.
  • Extending support for all atom types, enhancing the versatility of the library.
  • Developing new models that combine occupation and spin-based Hamiltonians.

Quantum Solids Lab

Instrumentation Engineer Intern - September 2021 - August 2023

Developed an automated system for producing metallic probes with nanometer precision, designed for cryogenic AFM(Atomic Force Microscopy) and MFM(Magnetic Force Microscopy)

Key Contribuitions:

  • Automated the electrochemical "drop-off" process using a Microcontroller-based control system.
  • Designed a current amplifier and comparator for precise electrochemical process control.
  • Integrated stepper motor for fine control of probe movement.
  • Improved reproducibility and precision in the fabrication of AFM and MFM probes for nanometer-scale topographical and magnetic imaging.

BdG-Machine Learning - Correlated Electrons Group

Researcher in Superconductivity and Machine Learning - February 2022 - July 2022

Optimizing Superconductivity Simulations with Bogoliubov–de Gennes (BdG) and Machine Learning (ML) Methods

Key Contribuitions:

  • Reduced computational time for solving BdG equations by integrating machine learning (Random Forest) for improving initial guesses of the superconducting gap (Δ).
  • Implemented models for one-dimensional systems with periodic and non-periodic boundary conditions, both in continuous and discrete space.
  • Achieved a twofold increase in computational speed while solving for Δ in continuous space simulations.
  • Discovered potential new physical behaviors for conditions where V≈t, suggesting unusual phase transitions in the bulk and at the edges.

The objective of the Master's in Data Science is to train experts in the field. By the end of the program, students acquire skills in statistical learning mathematics, deep learning, reinforcement learning, optimization, and big data infrastructures, among others. These competencies are particularly honed through practical projects and data science competitions. The program is part of the Statistics and Applied Mathematics departments, further emphasizing its strong theoretical and applied foundations.

BdG-Machine Learning

Link to the project

Mean-field approximations are useful in determining numerical values for order parameters in phase transitions like in superconductivity. Considering the computational complexities of iterativaly diagonalizations in a self consistent approach, one might wonder: could a machine learn the patterns existing in the determination of Δ and find a function f such that Δ ← f(T,V,N,Ec,etc)?

The project aimed to answer this question by training a Random Forest model to predict the superconducting gap Δ in a 1D system with periodic and non-periodic boundary conditions. The model was trained on a dataset of 1000 samples, each with 10 features, and achieved a twofold increase in computational speed while solving for Δ in continuous space simulations. The results also suggested potential new physical behaviors for conditions where V≈t, indicating unusual phase transitions in the bulk and at the edges.

Python Sickit-Learn Random Forest Mathematical Physics Optimization

Neural Networks for Artistic Style Transfer

Link to the project

Could a machine learn to recreate the unique brushstrokes of Van Gogh or the textures of the Mona Lisa while preserving the essence of a modern photograph? This project aimed to answer that question by applying neural networks to the artistic challenge of style transfer. Our goal was to take the stylistic elements of renowned artworks, like the swirling patterns of Van Gogh’s Starry Night or the fine details of the Mona Lisa, and seamlessly apply them to photographs, while keeping the original colors and content intact.

We used a modified version of the Gatys et al. neural style transfer algorithm, designed to selectively transfer textures and artistic features through different layers of the network. The result? A balanced fusion of style and content, where the artistic feel of the painting meets the structural integrity of the photograph, without losing its natural color.

Python Pytorch Cuda OpenCv CNN - VGG-19 Image Processing

Skin Lesion Classification

Link to the project

Detecting and classifying skin lesions is key to diagnosing various skin conditions, including skin cancer, which is a major global health concern. Computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) systems have become promising tools in this area, providing efficient and accurate ways to classify lesions. By integrating machine learning algorithms with medical imaging, CAD systems offer valuable support to doctors, helping them make quick and informed decisions for diagnosis and treatment planning.

In this context, this project the development and results of skin lesion classification into eight different diagnostic categories.

Python Pytorch Cuda OpenCv CNN - VGG-19 Image Processing

Skin Lesion Classification

Link to the project

Detecting and classifying skin lesions is key to diagnosing various skin conditions, including skin cancer, which is a major global health concern. Computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) systems have become promising tools in this area, providing efficient and accurate ways to classify lesions. By integrating machine learning algorithms with medical imaging, CAD systems offer valuable support to doctors, helping them make quick and informed decisions for diagnosis and treatment planning.

Python Sickit-Learn Random Forest Mathematical Physics Optimization

ModelHamiltonian: A Quantum Chemestry Library

Link to the project

I contributed to the development of a Open-Source Python library that generates 1- and 2-electron integrals for molecular quantum chemistry simulations. This software allows the simulation of new molecules and provides data for machine learning applications.

My work involved designing user-friendly APIs for Pariser-Parr-Pople approximations, extending support to include all atom types, and developing new models that integrate occupation- and spin-based Hamiltonians.

Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) Software Development Quantum Chemestry Git

Skin Lesion Segmentation

Link to the project

In the medical field, accurate segmentation plays a critical role in diagnosing conditions like skin cancer. By precisely extracting the lesion area from the surrounding skin, segmentation allows healthcare professionals to focus on the affected region, leading to more accurate diagnoses and informed treatment plans. Segmentation also enhances machine learning workflows, acting as a vital pre-processing step that improves classification performance by providing clean, well-defined inputs.

This project aimed to implement a segmentation pipeline to extract lesion areas from skin lesion images, using classical image processing techniques. As part of Télécom Paris's Image Processing course, the project successfully applied these tools to address a real-world medical challenge. The pipeline achieved impressive results, with a Dice coefficient exceeding 80%, demonstrating its high accuracy and effectiveness. Below are examples of the pipeline's output, highlighting its capability in extracting lesion areas.

Python Scikit-Image OpenCV Otsu Inpainting

Energy Prediction using Satellite Night-Time Data and LSTM

Link to the project

This project explores how nighttime satellite imagery can be utilized to predict energy consumption in the state of Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil. Using data from the VIIRS-DNB satellite and the Brazilian Energy Research Company (EPE), we performed econometric analyses including correlation and causality to evaluate the relationship between luminosity and energy consumption.

We compared ARIMA and LSTM models with and without the luminosity variable to assess their forecasting effectiveness. Preliminary results indicate that including nighttime luminosity data improves energy consumption predictions, providing a low-cost approach for optimizing energy management.

Python LSTM ARIMA Time Series Forecasting Satellite Data
